Check Normality Assumption (Gold Standard)

Source: R/assumptions.R
check_normality.Rd

Tests whether data follows a normal distribution using the Shapiro-Wilk test. Provides comprehensive interpretation for beginners, including visual diagnostics, educational explanations, and APA 7 formatted results.

This function is designed to be self-explanatory for users new to statistics, with extensive validation and beginner-friendly error messages.

Usage

check_normality(data, variable_name = "data", alpha = 0.05)

Arguments

data

Numeric vector to test for normality

variable_name

Character string naming the variable (for reporting). Default is "data". Used in all output messages.

alpha

Numeric. Significance level for the test (default 0.05). Must be between 0 and 1.

Value

An S3 object of class "assumption_check" containing:

  • test: Name of the test ("Shapiro-Wilk")

  • assumption: Which assumption was tested ("Normality")

  • assumption_met: Logical. TRUE if assumption is met (p > alpha)

  • p_value: P-value from Shapiro-Wilk test (APA 7 formatted)

  • statistic: W statistic (ranges 0-1, higher = more normal)

  • n: Sample size (after removing NA)

  • n_missing: Number of NA values removed

  • alpha: Significance level used

  • skewness: Measure of asymmetry (0 = symmetric)

  • kurtosis: Measure of tail heaviness (0 = normal tails)

  • interpretation: One-sentence summary for quick reference

  • recommendation: Actionable next steps

  • publication_text: APA 7 formatted text for manuscripts

  • verbose_explanation: Educational explanation for beginners

  • visual_guide: How to create diagnostic plots

Details

**What is the normality assumption?**

Many statistical tests (t-tests, ANOVA, linear regression) assume that data follows a "normal distribution" (bell-shaped curve). This function tests whether your data meets this assumption.

**How to interpret results:** - If p > 0.05: Normality assumption is MET (good news!) - If p < 0.05: Normality assumption is VIOLATED (need alternatives)

**What to do if violated:** 1. Use non-parametric tests (don't assume normality) 2. Transform data (log, square root, Box-Cox) 3. If n > 30, parametric tests often still work (Central Limit Theorem)

Examples

# Example 1: Normal data
normal_data <- rnorm(100, mean = 5, sd = 1)
check_normality(normal_data, "satisfaction_scores")

#> STATISTICAL ASSUMPTION CHECK: Normality
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===

#> ===

#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===

#> ===

#> ===

#> 
#> Test Used: Shapiro-Wilk 
#> Result: FAIL ASSUMPTION VIOLATED 
#> p-value: 3e-04 
#> Sample size: 100 
#> 
#> INTERPRETATION:
#>   The normality assumption is VIOLATED for satisfaction_scores (Shapiro-Wilk W
#>   = 0.943, p < .001, p < 0.05).
#> 
#> 
#> RECOMMENDATION:
#>   Consider: (1) Using non-parametric alternatives (e.g., Mann-Whitney U instead
#>   of t-test, Kruskal-Wallis instead of ANOVA), (2) Transforming the data (log,
#>   square root, Box-Cox), or (3) If sample size is large (n > 30), parametric
#>   tests may still be robust due to the Central Limit Theorem. Your sample size
#>   is 100.
#> 
#> 
#> PUBLICATION-READY TEXT:
#>   Data normality was assessed using the Shapiro-Wilk test. The
#>   satisfaction_scores variable violated the normality assumption (W = 0.943, p
#>   < .001). Accordingly, non-parametric tests were employed.
#> 
#>

#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> DETAILED EXPLANATION (for learning and context):
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> 
#>   The Shapiro-Wilk test evaluates whether a sample comes from a normally
#>   distributed population. The null hypothesis states that the data are normally
#>   distributed. With a p-value of 3e-04 (which is less than our alpha level of
#>   0.05), we reject the null hypothesis. This means we have strong evidence that
#>   the data significantly deviate from a normal distribution.
#>   
#>   In practical terms: Your data for satisfaction_scores does NOT follow a
#>   bell-shaped (normal) distribution. This is actually quite common in
#>   real-world consumer research data. When normality is violated, you have
#>   several options:
#>   
#>   1. USE NON-PARAMETRIC TESTS: These tests don't assume normality and are
#>   perfectly valid. Examples include Mann-Whitney U test (instead of t-test),
#>   Kruskal-Wallis test (instead of ANOVA), and Spearman correlation (instead of
#>   Pearson).
#>   
#>   2. TRANSFORM YOUR DATA: Sometimes a mathematical transformation (like taking
#>   the log or square root) can make skewed data more normal. However, remember
#>   that you'll be analyzing the transformed values, which can make
#>   interpretation more complex.
#>   
#>   3. PROCEED WITH CAUTION IF SAMPLE IS LARGE: If you have a large sample
#>   (typically n > 30 per group), parametric tests are often still robust to
#>   violations of normality due to the Central Limit Theorem. Your sample size is
#>   100.
#>   
#>   Technical details: The Shapiro-Wilk W statistic of 0.943 indicates deviation
#>   from normality. Skewness = 0.874 (positive values indicate right skew,
#>   negative indicate left skew), and excess kurtosis = 0.543 (positive values
#>   indicate heavy tails, negative indicate light tails).
#> 
#> 
#> ========================================================================
#> VISUAL DIAGNOSTICS: How to Check Normality with Plots
#> ========================================================================
#> 
#> Creating diagnostic plots is often more informative than statistical tests alone.
#> Here's how to create and interpret the two most useful plots:
#> 
#> --- Q-Q PLOT (Quantile-Quantile Plot) ---
#> 
#> Create the plot:
#>   qqnorm(your_data, main = "Q-Q Plot: satisfaction_scores")
#>   qqline(your_data, col = "red")
#> 
#> How to interpret:
#>   • Points fall ON the red line = Normal distribution ✓
#>   • Points curve ABOVE the line at ends = Heavy tails (outliers)
#>   • Points curve BELOW the line at ends = Light tails (no outliers)
#>   • S-shaped curve = Skewed distribution
#>   • Systematic deviation = Non-normal
#> 
#> What's considered 'good enough':
#>   - Some deviation is normal, especially at the extremes
#>   - Focus on the middle 80% of points
#>   - Minor wiggles are OK; systematic patterns are concerning
#> 
#> --- HISTOGRAM WITH NORMAL CURVE ---
#> 
#> Create the plot:
#>   hist(your_data, 
#>        breaks = 20,
#>        prob = TRUE,
#>        main = "Distribution of satisfaction_scores",
#>        xlab = "satisfaction_scores",
#>        col = "lightblue")
#>   curve(dnorm(x, mean = mean(your_data), sd = sd(your_data)),
#>         add = TRUE, col = "red", lwd = 2)
#> 
#> How to interpret:
#>   • Bell-shaped curve = Likely normal ✓
#>   • Long tail on right = Positive skew (common in income, prices)
#>   • Long tail on left = Negative skew (common in test scores near max)
#>   • Two peaks = Bimodal (may have two subgroups)
#>   • Flat distribution = Uniform (not normal)
#> 
#> --- COMBINED DIAGNOSTIC CODE ---
#> 
#> Run both plots side-by-side:
#>   par(mfrow = c(1, 2))  # Create 2-panel layout
#>   
#>   # Q-Q Plot
#>   qqnorm(your_data, main = "Q-Q Plot")
#>   qqline(your_data, col = "red")
#>   
#>   # Histogram
#>   hist(your_data, prob = TRUE, main = "Distribution",
#>        col = "lightblue", breaks = 20)
#>   curve(dnorm(x, mean = mean(your_data), sd = sd(your_data)),
#>         add = TRUE, col = "red", lwd = 2)
#>   
#>   par(mfrow = c(1, 1))  # Reset layout
#> 
#> YOUR DATA CHARACTERISTICS:
#>   Sample size:  100
#>   Mean:         5
#>   SD:           0.93
#>   Skewness:     0.874 (approximately symmetric)
#>   Kurtosis:     0.543 (normal tails)
#> 
#> PRACTICAL ADVICE:
#>   • With n < 30: Visual inspection is more reliable than statistical tests
#>   • With n > 100: Tests become very sensitive; focus on practical importance
#>   • Mild violations + large sample = Usually OK to proceed with parametric tests
#>   • Severe violations = Use non-parametric tests or transformations
#> ========================================================================
#> 

# Example 2: Skewed data (not normal)
skewed_data <- rexp(100, rate = 0.5)
check_normality(skewed_data, "income")
#>

#> 
#> Test Used: Shapiro-Wilk 
#> Result: FAIL ASSUMPTION VIOLATED 
#> p-value: 0 
#> Sample size: 100 
#> 
#> INTERPRETATION:
#>   The normality assumption is VIOLATED for income (Shapiro-Wilk W = 0.8255, p <
#>   .001, p < 0.05).
#> 
#> 
#> RECOMMENDATION:
#>   Consider: (1) Using non-parametric alternatives (e.g., Mann-Whitney U instead
#>   of t-test, Kruskal-Wallis instead of ANOVA), (2) Transforming the data (log,
#>   square root, Box-Cox), or (3) If sample size is large (n > 30), parametric
#>   tests may still be robust due to the Central Limit Theorem. Your sample size
#>   is 100.
#>   
#>   TRANSFORMATION SUGGESTION: Your data shows positive skew (1.471), meaning it
#>   has a long right tail. Try these transformations in order: 1. Log
#>   transformation: log_income <- log(income) 2. Square root: sqrt_income <-
#>   sqrt(income) Note: Log requires all positive values. If you have zeros, use
#>   log(income + 1).
#> 
#> 
#> PUBLICATION-READY TEXT:
#>   Data normality was assessed using the Shapiro-Wilk test. The income variable
#>   violated the normality assumption (W = 0.8255, p < .001). Accordingly,
#>   non-parametric tests were employed.
#> 
#>

#> ---
#> ---

#> ---

#> DETAILED EXPLANATION (for learning and context):
#> ---
#> ---

#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---

#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> 
#>   The Shapiro-Wilk test evaluates whether a sample comes from a normally
#>   distributed population. The null hypothesis states that the data are normally
#>   distributed. With a p-value of 0 (which is less than our alpha level of
#>   0.05), we reject the null hypothesis. This means we have strong evidence that
#>   the data significantly deviate from a normal distribution.
#>   
#>   In practical terms: Your data for income does NOT follow a bell-shaped
#>   (normal) distribution. This is actually quite common in real-world consumer
#>   research data. When normality is violated, you have several options:
#>   
#>   1. USE NON-PARAMETRIC TESTS: These tests don't assume normality and are
#>   perfectly valid. Examples include Mann-Whitney U test (instead of t-test),
#>   Kruskal-Wallis test (instead of ANOVA), and Spearman correlation (instead of
#>   Pearson).
#>   
#>   2. TRANSFORM YOUR DATA: Sometimes a mathematical transformation (like taking
#>   the log or square root) can make skewed data more normal. However, remember
#>   that you'll be analyzing the transformed values, which can make
#>   interpretation more complex.
#>   
#>   TRANSFORMATION SUGGESTION: Your data shows positive skew (1.471), meaning it
#>   has a long right tail. Try these transformations in order: 1. Log
#>   transformation: log_income <- log(income) 2. Square root: sqrt_income <-
#>   sqrt(income) Note: Log requires all positive values. If you have zeros, use
#>   log(income + 1).
#>   
#>   3. PROCEED WITH CAUTION IF SAMPLE IS LARGE: If you have a large sample
#>   (typically n > 30 per group), parametric tests are often still robust to
#>   violations of normality due to the Central Limit Theorem. Your sample size is
#>   100.
#>   
#>   Technical details: The Shapiro-Wilk W statistic of 0.8255 indicates deviation
#>   from normality. Skewness = 1.471 (positive values indicate right skew,
#>   negative indicate left skew), and excess kurtosis = 1.525 (positive values
#>   indicate heavy tails, negative indicate light tails).
#> 
#> 
#> ========================================================================
#> VISUAL DIAGNOSTICS: How to Check Normality with Plots
#> ========================================================================
#> 
#> Creating diagnostic plots is often more informative than statistical tests alone.
#> Here's how to create and interpret the two most useful plots:
#> 
#> --- Q-Q PLOT (Quantile-Quantile Plot) ---
#> 
#> Create the plot:
#>   qqnorm(your_data, main = "Q-Q Plot: income")
#>   qqline(your_data, col = "red")
#> 
#> How to interpret:
#>   • Points fall ON the red line = Normal distribution ✓
#>   • Points curve ABOVE the line at ends = Heavy tails (outliers)
#>   • Points curve BELOW the line at ends = Light tails (no outliers)
#>   • S-shaped curve = Skewed distribution
#>   • Systematic deviation = Non-normal
#> 
#> What's considered 'good enough':
#>   - Some deviation is normal, especially at the extremes
#>   - Focus on the middle 80% of points
#>   - Minor wiggles are OK; systematic patterns are concerning
#> 
#> --- HISTOGRAM WITH NORMAL CURVE ---
#> 
#> Create the plot:
#>   hist(your_data, 
#>        breaks = 20,
#>        prob = TRUE,
#>        main = "Distribution of income",
#>        xlab = "income",
#>        col = "lightblue")
#>   curve(dnorm(x, mean = mean(your_data), sd = sd(your_data)),
#>         add = TRUE, col = "red", lwd = 2)
#> 
#> How to interpret:
#>   • Bell-shaped curve = Likely normal ✓
#>   • Long tail on right = Positive skew (common in income, prices)
#>   • Long tail on left = Negative skew (common in test scores near max)
#>   • Two peaks = Bimodal (may have two subgroups)
#>   • Flat distribution = Uniform (not normal)
#> 
#> --- COMBINED DIAGNOSTIC CODE ---
#> 
#> Run both plots side-by-side:
#>   par(mfrow = c(1, 2))  # Create 2-panel layout
#>   
#>   # Q-Q Plot
#>   qqnorm(your_data, main = "Q-Q Plot")
#>   qqline(your_data, col = "red")
#>   
#>   # Histogram
#>   hist(your_data, prob = TRUE, main = "Distribution",
#>        col = "lightblue", breaks = 20)
#>   curve(dnorm(x, mean = mean(your_data), sd = sd(your_data)),
#>         add = TRUE, col = "red", lwd = 2)
#>   
#>   par(mfrow = c(1, 1))  # Reset layout
#> 
#> YOUR DATA CHARACTERISTICS:
#>   Sample size:  100
#>   Mean:         1.82
#>   SD:           1.83
#>   Skewness:     1.471 (right-skewed)
#>   Kurtosis:     1.525 (heavy-tailed)
#> 
#> PRACTICAL ADVICE:
#>   • With n < 30: Visual inspection is more reliable than statistical tests
#>   • With n > 100: Tests become very sensitive; focus on practical importance
#>   • Mild violations + large sample = Usually OK to proceed with parametric tests
#>   • Severe violations = Use non-parametric tests or transformations
#> ========================================================================
#> 

# Example 3: With missing values
data_with_na <- c(rnorm(95), NA, NA, NA, NA, NA)
check_normality(data_with_na, "responses")
#> Note: 5 missing value(s) removed from normality test (5% of data)
#>

#> 
#> Test Used: Shapiro-Wilk 
#> Result: PASS ASSUMPTION MET 
#> p-value: 0.957 
#> Sample size: 95 
#> 
#> INTERPRETATION:
#>   The normality assumption is MET for responses (Shapiro-Wilk W = 0.9942, p =
#>   .957, p > 0.05).
#> 
#> 
#> RECOMMENDATION:
#>   Parametric tests (e.g., t-tests, ANOVA, linear regression) are appropriate.
#>   The data distribution does not significantly deviate from normality.
#> 
#> 
#> PUBLICATION-READY TEXT:
#>   Data normality was assessed using the Shapiro-Wilk test. The responses
#>   variable met the normality assumption (W = 0.9942, p = .957).

#> DETAILED EXPLANATION (for learning and context):
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---

#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> 
#>   The Shapiro-Wilk test evaluates whether a sample comes from a normally
#>   distributed population. The null hypothesis states that the data are normally
#>   distributed. With a p-value of 0.957 (which is greater than our alpha level
#>   of 0.05), we fail to reject the null hypothesis. This means we do not have
#>   sufficient evidence to conclude that the data significantly deviate from a
#>   normal distribution.
#>   
#>   In practical terms: Your data for responses appears to follow a bell-shaped
#>   (normal) distribution, which is excellent news. This means you can proceed
#>   with parametric statistical tests that assume normality (such as t-tests,
#>   ANOVA, and linear regression) with confidence. These tests tend to be more
#>   powerful than their non-parametric alternatives when assumptions are met.
#>   
#>   Technical details: The Shapiro-Wilk W statistic ranges from 0 to 1, with
#>   values closer to 1 indicating better fit to normality. Your W value of 0.9942
#>   suggests a good fit. Skewness = -0.183 (values near 0 indicate symmetry), and
#>   excess kurtosis = -0.017 (values near 0 indicate normal tail behavior).
#> 
#> 
#> ========================================================================
#> VISUAL DIAGNOSTICS: How to Check Normality with Plots
#> ========================================================================
#> 
#> Creating diagnostic plots is often more informative than statistical tests alone.
#> Here's how to create and interpret the two most useful plots:
#> 
#> --- Q-Q PLOT (Quantile-Quantile Plot) ---
#> 
#> Create the plot:
#>   qqnorm(your_data, main = "Q-Q Plot: responses")
#>   qqline(your_data, col = "red")
#> 
#> How to interpret:
#>   • Points fall ON the red line = Normal distribution ✓
#>   • Points curve ABOVE the line at ends = Heavy tails (outliers)
#>   • Points curve BELOW the line at ends = Light tails (no outliers)
#>   • S-shaped curve = Skewed distribution
#>   • Systematic deviation = Non-normal
#> 
#> What's considered 'good enough':
#>   - Some deviation is normal, especially at the extremes
#>   - Focus on the middle 80% of points
#>   - Minor wiggles are OK; systematic patterns are concerning
#> 
#> --- HISTOGRAM WITH NORMAL CURVE ---
#> 
#> Create the plot:
#>   hist(your_data, 
#>        breaks = 20,
#>        prob = TRUE,
#>        main = "Distribution of responses",
#>        xlab = "responses",
#>        col = "lightblue")
#>   curve(dnorm(x, mean = mean(your_data), sd = sd(your_data)),
#>         add = TRUE, col = "red", lwd = 2)
#> 
#> How to interpret:
#>   • Bell-shaped curve = Likely normal ✓
#>   • Long tail on right = Positive skew (common in income, prices)
#>   • Long tail on left = Negative skew (common in test scores near max)
#>   • Two peaks = Bimodal (may have two subgroups)
#>   • Flat distribution = Uniform (not normal)
#> 
#> --- COMBINED DIAGNOSTIC CODE ---
#> 
#> Run both plots side-by-side:
#>   par(mfrow = c(1, 2))  # Create 2-panel layout
#>   
#>   # Q-Q Plot
#>   qqnorm(your_data, main = "Q-Q Plot")
#>   qqline(your_data, col = "red")
#>   
#>   # Histogram
#>   hist(your_data, prob = TRUE, main = "Distribution",
#>        col = "lightblue", breaks = 20)
#>   curve(dnorm(x, mean = mean(your_data), sd = sd(your_data)),
#>         add = TRUE, col = "red", lwd = 2)
#>   
#>   par(mfrow = c(1, 1))  # Reset layout
#> 
#> YOUR DATA CHARACTERISTICS:
#>   Sample size:  95 (5 missing)
#>   Mean:         -0.09
#>   SD:           1.03
#>   Skewness:     -0.183 (approximately symmetric)
#>   Kurtosis:     -0.017 (normal tails)
#> 
#> PRACTICAL ADVICE:
#>   • With n < 30: Visual inspection is more reliable than statistical tests
#>   • With n > 100: Tests become very sensitive; focus on practical importance
#>   • Mild violations + large sample = Usually OK to proceed with parametric tests
#>   • Severe violations = Use non-parametric tests or transformations
#> ========================================================================
#>
